title: The Alphabet (N - Ω) & Diphthongs (OY, AI, EI).
reading_greek: Ο Νίκος έχει ένα όνειρο. Θέλει να πάει στην Ουαλία. Εκεί θα βρει ωραίο καιρό. Ουαί!
reading_english: Nikos has a dream. He wants to go to Wales. There he will find nice weather. Alas!
audio_script: Welcome to Week 1, Part 2 of our Greek lesson. Today we focus on the second half of the Greek alphabet, from Ni to Omega, and we introduce three important diphthongs: Opsilon-Ypsilon, Alpha-Iota, and Epsilon-Iota. ... The letters are: Ni, Xi, Omicron, Pi, Rho, Sigma, Tau, Ypsilon, Phi, Chi, Psi, and Omega. ... Let's practice the diphthongs. ... Opsilon-Ypsilon, written as O-Y, sounds like 'oo' in 'food'. ... Alpha-Iota, written as A-I, sounds like 'ay' in 'day' or 'eye' in older pronunciation. We will use the 'ay' sound primarily. ... Epsilon-Iota, written as E-I, sounds like 'ee' in 'see'. ... Now, let's look at a short reading passage that uses these sounds. Listen carefully to the pronunciation: ... 'Ο Νίκος έχει ένα όνειρο. Θέλει να πάει στην Ουαλία. Εκεί θα βρει ωραίο καιρό. Ουαί!' ... Now, let's break down some of the words focusing on the new sounds. 'Νίκος' uses Ni. ... 'Όνειρο' uses Omicron. ... 'Ουαλία' starts with the OY diphthong, sounding 'oo'. ... 'Πάει' uses the AI diphthong, sounding 'ay'. ... 'Εκεί' uses the EI diphthong, sounding 'ee'. ... Repeat the passage after me: 'Ο Νίκος έχει ένα όνειρο. Θέλει να πάει στην Ουαλία. Εκεί θα βρει ωραίο καιρό. Ουαί!'. ... Excellent work. Remember these new letters and diphthongs for our next session.
